• Dozens of computational methods are developed for intra-species protein-protein interaction prediction, however, inter-species predictions are limited in number of publications, scope of species and mechanisms.
  • Traditionally, protein-protein interaction prediction relies on homology, sequence/domain/structural similarities to the known PPIs. Deep neural network offers a different approach to identify the underlying features that suggest PPIs.
  • In this project, I develop a computational pipeline systematically screen the combinations of human and gut microbiome proteins.

frontmatter.title: scRNAseq
frontmatter.range: single cell RNA sequencing, 10X genomics, Seurat, Scanpy, scVI-tools

node.html:
• The rapid development of sequencing and mass spectrometry technologies has enabled the full power of big data analysis. Genomic, transcriptomic, proteomic, phospho-proteomic, and metabolomic data are all rapidly expanding. Each of these data types contains valuable information for researchers. But what about the interactions between different "omics"?
  • Can we view the central dogma as a sequential projection of omics data? For example, considering the transcriptome as a projection of the genome, the proteome as a projection of the transcriptome, and the metabolome as a projection of the proteome.
  • Macrophage plays a critical role in moderating the immunological homeostasis in the gut. How does it responses to various bacterial species is unknown. And we are interested in answering this question with scRNAseq to capture the subtle dynamics in transcriptional level.

• Besides my role as a researcher trainee, I am passionate in sharing my experience in my career path from a biochemist to a computational biologist, and introducing computational biology papers for biologists.
  • My blog will focus on the following topics:
    • Development environment setup,
    • My experience in changing academic focus,
    • Paper reviews in computational biology and deep learning.
